message_1:
Let P be the set of all prime numbers, and let Q be the set of all rational numbers between 0 and 1. Determine the truth value of the following statement in second-order logic:

"For every prime number p and every rational number q between 0 and 1, either p or 1-p is not in Q." 

In other words, prove or disprove whether for all primes and rationals between 0 and 1, at least one of the numbers p or 1-p is not in the set of rationals between 0 and 1.
message_2:
The statement is true. To prove this, we will show that for every prime number p and every rational number q between 0 and 1, either p or 1-p is not in Q.

First, let's consider the prime number p. Since p is a prime number, it must be greater than 1 (as the smallest prime number is 2). Therefore, p cannot be in the set Q, as Q contains only rational numbers between 0 and 1.

Now, let's consider the number 1-p. Since p is greater than 1, 1-p will be a negative number. As Q contains only rational numbers between 0 and 1, 1-p cannot be in the set Q either.

Thus, for every prime number p and every rational number q between 0 and 1, either p or 1-p is not in Q. This proves the statement is true.
